title: How Long Should a Couple Go Without Having Sex? Your Questions Answered

steps.title: As long as you communicate with your partner, there’s no right answer to this.
steps.content: As long as you communicate with your partner, there’s no right answer to this. For some couples, having sex every day is the norm. For other couples, once or twice a month might be their sweet spot. [1] X Research source The important part here is to talk with your partner about their preferences and your own preferences. On average, most couples have sex about once a week. If you or your partner is going through something (loss of a loved one, depression, high stress levels, etc.), sex might temporarily take a backseat. Rest assured that once you’re both feeling normal again, your sex life will likely improve. If sex is on the backburner right now, focus on building intimacy in other ways. Cuddle with each other, have deep conversations , and stay connected as a couple. Reader Poll: We asked 311 wikiHow readers how they like to discuss their needs with their partner, and 62% of them agreed that they prefer open and honest communication without judgment. [Take Poll] Remember, your partner wants you to be happy, so don’t be afraid to tell them what you want or need in regards to intimacy.

steps.title: Sex is bonding and brings you two closer together.
steps.content: Sex is bonding and brings you two closer together. When you have sex in a relationship, it’s a great way to build intimacy and feel closer to your partner. While sex definitely isn’t the only way to build a healthy relationship , many people find that an active sex life improves their relationship with their partner. [2] X Research source Sex has other, individual health benefits, too. Studies have shown that sex can lower your blood pressure, relieve pain, and even help you sleep.

steps.title: Children and other responsibilities
steps.content: Children and other responsibilities As your relationship progresses, you both have more on your plate. Raising children is very stressful, and lots of parents find that their sex life declines after introducing a child (or children) into the mix. [3] X Research source Even if you don’t have children, work and other responsibilities can leave you feeling drained and too tired to have sex.

steps.title: End of the honeymoon period
steps.content: End of the honeymoon period The honeymoon period is the stage when everything in the relationship is new and exciting. As that stage winds down (usually after 1 year or so), you might find that your sex life becomes a little more routine. This can cause it to slow down, and in turn, lead to having less sex. [4] X Research source While the end of the honeymoon period can sound a little sad, it just means that you and your partner are truly close and connected. Instead of discovering new things about each other, you can now grow and evolve together as a couple.

steps.title: Libido mismatch
steps.content: Libido mismatch When one partner has a high libido (wanting sex more often) and the other partner has a low libido (wanting sex less often), your sex life might slow down. [5] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source While it is totally possible to have a fulfilling relationship with 2 different libidos, it’s important to talk to your partner and make your needs known so that you’re both happy.

steps.title: Menopause or aging
steps.content: Menopause or aging Both menopause and getting older can have an effect on your hormones, making your libido lower. [6] X Trustworthy Source Johns Hopkins Medicine Official resource database of the world-leading Johns Hopkins Hospital Go to source As you and your partner grow old, you might find that one or both of you is less interested in having sex.

steps.title: Mental health or self-esteem issues
steps.content: Mental health or self-esteem issues Anxiety, depression, low self-esteem, and tons of other mental health problems can lead to a lowered sex drive. [7] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source It’s possible that you or your partner might be struggling with a new or recurring issue, which is affecting your sex life. Certain medications for mental health issues can also lower your libido, leading to a lowered desire for sex.

steps.title: Lack of respect or trust in a partner
steps.content: Lack of respect or trust in a partner If either you or your partner is not happy in the relationship, that could be a reason why your sex life is on the decline. Think about your relationship as a whole: are you having problems or fighting a lot? If so, try working on those issues before addressing your lack of sex. [8] X Research source If you’ve tried working through your problems together and aren’t making much headway, consider seeing a couple’s counselor. They can give you an unbiased, third-party perspective as well as tools to repair your relationship.

steps.title: Negative feelings about the relationship
steps.content: Negative feelings about the relationship When you’re in a relationship that doesn’t include sex, it can cause you to question a lot of things. You might wonder whether you’re a good partner or not, whether this is the right relationship for you, or whether you’re happy in this relationship. Over time, these thoughts can get louder, and can even lead to ending the relationship. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Unhappiness about sex itself
steps.content: Unhappiness about sex itself Even if you do still have sex occasionally, it might not be the most satisfying. Whether that’s because your partner isn’t putting in enough effort or because you’re just waiting for your sex life to dwindle again, you may find that you aren’t finding satisfaction in sex like you used to. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Exacerbates other relationship problems
steps.content: Exacerbates other relationship problems Many couples find that sex brings them closer together and strengthens their bond. If you aren’t having sex, you might find that your relationship problems seem even larger. This is because you’re missing that key bonding experience that you’ve learned to love. [11] X Research source

steps.title: A sexless marriage is fine as long as both partners are happy with it.
steps.content: A sexless marriage is fine as long as both partners are happy with it. There are many reasons why you might be in a sexless marriage, including asexuality, religious practices, avoiding pregnancy, or equally low sex drives. If you and your partner have sex infrequently and you’re both content, then your relationship doesn’t need to change. [12] X Research source If you’re in a sexless marriage and you’re not happy with it, open the line of communication by talking with your partner. Use “I” statements to start a discussion without making your partner feel attacked. If you’ve tried talking to your partner about sex and it’s not productive, consider seeing a couple’s counselor. Someone who specializes in relationships will help you navigate discussions about sex.
